results.title: Digital Diaries for Memory Grid Pods. Tape 1
results.brief_description: Works produced from the digital diaires program collected at the discretion of the program coordiantors. all submissions are anonymous. The Digital Diary project asks a diverse range of young people to share a personal story as they connect memories by way of simple moving images. Participants in the workshops look at one ‘moment’ in their lives and, concentrating on the simplicity and power of that one moment in time, they create a ‘lo-fi’ video work that speaks to the mind and heart. The story is then burnt to a CD (or put onto VHS) for the participants to keep, and the monologues become part of a specially curated database which, with the participant’s permission, is later screened at the Australian Centre for the Moving Image at Federation Square.

results.title: Booth at ACMI
results.brief_description:
The Booth at ACMI is an intimate venue designed for the exhibition of short custom made audio visual works. A cross between the world’s smallest cinema and largest photobooth with a companion Boothsite that can take the portraits of Booth visitors generated by the encounter and admit them into a growing, online, interactive community of Booth visitors.
It is a coin-operated vending machine that vends cinema itself and, like the black and white photobooth, provides its visitors with a take away souvenir record of their encounter in the form of a photographic portrait. It includes an evolving soundscape that shifts as day turns to night, enlivened by lighting that plays over and under the 120 mother of pearl discs in the Booth’s shell.

results.title: Casual menace
results.brief_description: Sleeping rough in bus shelters and roadside ditches from Darwin to Dubbo, the artists collect a large image-gallery of characters, landscapes, abstractions and moods. Using video and Super 8, they explore the alienating environments of the road and the lonesome souls who travel through these spaces and times. A dark meditation on the nomadic spaces of rural Australia, Casual Menace is composed of two interrelated video loops The Chance Map and Moths. Using the footage gathered from their numerous hitchhiking ‘experiments’, the artists explore the fragile, lonely spaces of remote highways.

results.title: Dial history
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and black and white and audio
results.brief_description: In the found footage tradition, ‘Dial H-I-S-T-O-R-Y’ takes the viewer on a journey through media footage of airplane hijacking and other terrorism.

results.title: The Journey
results.brief_description: An old man sits in a rowboat on an endless gravel ocean remembering episodes from his youth and middle age. The three vignettes presented in this film using model animation come to represent the old man’s search for spiritual meaning and purpose in his life. The tightrope becomes a metaphor for his precarious passage from boyhood to adulthood, while the door and ladder sequence comes to represent the man’s desire for meaning through material wealth. The final rowboat episode thus becomes the pinnacle of the man’s quest - a final search for fulfilment that will take him beyond life.

results.title: Under the weather
results.brief_description: In this whirlwind of stop motion animation, everday domestic objects are whipped into movement by a runaway weather report. A mixture of object animation and live action.

results.title: Serving suggestion
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Kate Riedl and Tony Thorne
results.brief_description: A snot nosed kid called Kevin eats his way through the snack aisle in the supermarket. When Kevin decides to go for the ‘Chocky Pops’, he doesn’t realise that he’ll end up with more than a mouthful. The supermarket becomes a jungle in this impressive computer animated short.

results.title: Pleasure domes
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Maggie Fooke
results.brief_description: Is Cannes really like St. Kilda, or is it just a state of mind? Animated watercolour drawings and hand coloured photocopies shape this introspective reflection on the nature of landscape and human responses to it. It hints that our perception of landscape is never direct but always filtered through a set of constructs, either physical or psychological.
